results.title: Access Video 1973-1982
results.creator_credit: Helen Eisler and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description:
This is a retrospective look at Access Video, an
independent public broadcasting project, using archival
footage shot over a period of nine years Australia wide.The images encapsulate Australian life on a social,
political and cultural level providing a historical glimpse
of the developing community and political activity during
the seventies whilst also illustrating the growth and
maturing of independent video within Australia. NB: Some
footage is of poor quality both in sound and image.

results.title: Cross my heart
results.creator_credit: David Swann, Andrew Wiseman, Open Channel Productions and Jocelyn Moorhouse
results.brief_description: Two women attending a friend’s funeral who died from cancer vow to quit smoking, cold turkey. There are obstacles in their way however, including a sister who has just split up with her partner, her son in tow. They instil a no smoking policy in the house with penalties for those who break the rules. Features salient points about the ill effects of smoking and the side effects you can expect when quitting. Cast includes: Marilyn O’Donnell, Parthena Amanatidis, Tamasin Ramsay, Brian Nankervis.

results.title: Another day, another dollar: three short films about the history of work
results.brief_description:
“Projected memories: work in old films”: In 1947, a projectionist took a collection of instructional 16mm films about work to the bush. This short film includes excerpts from that collection covering early footage (1900s-1930s) of families on the land; factory workers; steel workers; coal miners; working women; the rise of trade-unions and the 8-hour day; peace campaign of 1938; the invention of the teleprinter; the arrival of the corner grocer shop and much more.
“Never done: women, work and history”: Focuses on women in the workplace from the mid-1800s through to the 1970s including footage of the first women’s union (1882); industrialisation and factory work; the birth of the modern office worker (1890s); equal pay for equal work movement; WWI and WWII women in the workforce; trade-unionism and feminism.
“Close to slavery: black work in white history”: It was government policy for First Nations peoples in Australia to assimilate to the white ethics of education and work. Then came the mission stations, removal of children, forced labour often in the most deplorable conditions, exploitation and even when First Nations Australians were trained in skilled work through the mission stations, white Australians would not employ them - all this most comprehensively portrayed by the archival footage in this film.

results.title: The Last game
results.brief_description: An interactive CD-ROM following a ‘pick-a-path’ approach to a soccer player’s last match. A range of outcomes are generated in reaction to key elememts of a typical football game - penalty kick, injury, extra time. The CD-ROM attempts to describe the possible emotions of the player as he experiences the last game of his career.

results.title: Writers' block
results.brief_description: Writer’s block was developed as a character-driven interactive that gives the user the opportunity to view characters involved in the creative process of writing; including having trouble with muses and getting distracted by too many coffee breaks. The CDROM also contains practical information for would be authors ranging from getting started as a writer through to organising a poetry reading.

results.title: Lit's treasurehunt
results.brief_description:
Lit’s Treasurehunt is a multimedia game for children between the ages of 4 - 7. The main character, Lit, is stranded on an island. A pirate named One-eye asks Lit to help him recover his lost treasure. To do so, Lit has to explore the island and solve a series of tasks.

Lit’s Treasurehunt won the student multimedia catagorey of the Designation Awards, 2002.

results.title: Fair go!
results.creator_credit: Tony Wright, Penny Robbins, Open Channel Productions and Peter Moon
results.brief_description: “Fair go!” is a step towards meeting the needs of young people for information about their rights as workers. Using a fresh, entertaining presentation, the program follows the experiences of school-leavers Kelly and Sam, as they fall unawares into a series of near disasters in new jobs.
